SiO2-supported niobia catalyst with optimized acid concentration prepared via organic additive-assisted impregnation protocol for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal Kohta Horio Writing – original draft Visualization Investigation Data curation Enggah Kurniawan Writing – review & editing Visualization Investigation Data curation Saho Nakayama Formal analysis Data curation Takayoshi Hara Validation Data curation Takashi Kojima Validation Data curation Yasuhiro Yamada Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision Satoshi Sato Writing – review & editing Project administration Methodology Conceptualization ⁎ Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Japan ⁎ Correspondence to: 1-33 Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263-8522, Japan. 1-33 Yayoi, Inage Chiba 263-8522 Japan In this study, we prepared SiO2-supported niobium oxide (Nb/SiO2) catalysts with optimized acid concentrations using an organic additive (OA)-assisted impregnation protocol for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal to 2-ethyl-2-hexenal (2E2H). The inclusion of an OA, such as 18-crown-6-ether, during the impregnation process enhanced the acid concentration of the resulting Nb/SiO2 catalyst. This increase in acid concentration proved to be crucial for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H, as confirmed by a proportional correlation between the acid concentration and the formation rate of 2E2H. Additionally, the essential role of acid sites, in particular Brønsted acid sites, of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst was confirmed through poisoning experiments using several probe molecules, including NH3, CO2, and 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylpyridine. Several other parameters, such as Nb content and molar ratio of OA to Nb, also affected the catalytic activity of Nb/SiO2 catalyst. Graphical Abstract Keywords Butanal Aldol condensation Vapor phase Silica-supported niobia Organic additive-assisted impregnation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Green and sustainable technology, by the catalytic conversion of biomass-derived platform compounds, remains a promising alternative to address the global environmental issues caused by the continuous usage of fossil fuels [1–3]. The prospect of this technology has driven the development of many efficient catalytic designs. Among numerous catalytic transformations, aldol condensation is one of the essentials due to its ability to form the carbon-carbon bond, allowing this transformation to convert small molecules to larger ones [4–6]. With the variety of small carbonyl molecules derived from biomass and considering that these molecules often act as undesired side products, aldol condensation can transform these undesired molecules to generate more valuable chemicals. Nonetheless, this promising sustainable process can only be efficiently realized with efficient catalysts. Thus, the pursuit of an efficient catalyst for aldol condensation is imperative. Catalytic conversion of butanal to 2-ethyl-2-hexenal (2E2H) is one of the reaction models in aldol condensation ( Scheme 1) [4,7,8]. Several studies have indicated that butanal can be produced through microbial conversion of biomass [9–11], which further demonstrates the sustainable prospect of 2E2H production from butanal. The aldol condensation has been reported to be catalyzed by acid, base, and acid-base bifunctional catalysts [7]. The aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H is often coupled with a hydrogenation reaction to generate 2-ethyl-2-hexanol [12,13]. Several catalysts have been employed for the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H. Heterogeneous catalysts, in particular, have emerged as a promising alternative to homogeneous catalysts, such as NaOH and KOH, due to their green and sustainable nature [14,15]. It has been reported that solid base, acid, and acid-base bifunctional catalysts, such as supported alkali earth [4], alkali earth [14], zeolites [16,17], silica [8], and TiO2 [7], catalyze the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H. Supported acid catalysts have attracted considerable attention due to their versatility in numerous catalytic transformations [18–20]. One of the main advantages of the supported catalyst compared with the bulk one is that the supported catalysts often have a substantially larger surface area [21,22]. The small size of the sites that facilitate the catalytic transformation has also been reported to have unique properties that are beneficial for the catalytic process [22–24]. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of the supported catalyst can be further improved by reducing the size of the active site and increasing its dispersion on the support. Therefore, the supported catalyst can potentially be more efficient than its bulk counterparts. Numerous studies have been reported to increase the dispersion of the active site on the support [25–27]. In this regard, we have also demonstrated an efficient strategy of organic additive (OA)-assisted impregnation protocol to enhance the dispersion of the active sites for the Ni- and Cu-based catalysts [28–36]. We have exhibited that the enhancement of metal dispersion on the support strongly correlates with the improvement of the catalytic activity. Therefore, a similar strategy can be employed to generate an efficient silica-supported metal oxide catalyst for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H. In this work, vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal was performed over a SiO2-supported niobium oxide (Nb/SiO2) catalyst prepared with an OA-assisted impregnation protocol. Several types of OAs ( Fig. 1) were explored to determine the best OA to generate the most efficient catalyst for the aldol condensation of butanal. The use of OA was proven to increase the acid site concentration, which was proportional to the formation rate of 2E2H. 18-Crown-6-ether (18C6) acted as the most efficient OA to generate the Nb/SiO2 catalyst with the highest catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A SiO2 support material was supplied by Fuji Silysia Chemical Ltd., Japan. (CARiACT Q10, a specific surface area of 266 m2 g−1, a pore volume of 1.20 cm3 g−1, and a granule size of 75–500 μm). Ammonium niobium oxalate (NH4[NbO(C2O4)2(H2O)15], JRC-NBO-3AO), and niobia (Nb2O5, JRC-NBO-1) were supplied by the Catalysis Society of Japan as Japan Reference Catalyst. 12-Crown-4-ether (12C4), 15-crown-5-ether (15C5), and 18C6 were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. Triethylene glycol (TEG), citric acid (CA), and sorbitol (Sor) were purchased from Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical Corp. Nb/SiO2 catalysts were prepared via an OA-assisted impregnation protocol according to the previous literature [29,32]. The catalysts in this work are denoted as A-xNb/SiO2, where A and x represent the OA and the Nb content in mol%, respectively. Unless otherwise noted, the Nb/SiO2 catalysts were prepared with the molar ratio of OA to Nb of 1. For example, 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst means the Nb/SiO2 catalyst containing 2.0 mol% of Nb prepared with 18C6 as the OA. In this regard, 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the following method: NH4[NbO(C2O4)2(H2O)15] salt (0.3897 g, 0.680 mmol) and 18C6 (0.1798 g, 0.680 mmol) were dissolved into 12.0 cm3 of H2O. The solution was dropwisely added onto SiO2 support (2.0 g). A 350-W bulb was used to evaporate the water in the drop solution. This process was repeated until all solution containing the Nb precursor and 18C6 were added into the SiO2 support. After the addition process, the SiO2 support containing the desired amount of Nb-precursor and 18C6 was dried at 110 °C overnight. The as-dried sample was calcined at 500 °C in air for 3 h. Other A-xNb/SiO2 catalysts were prepared using a similar strategy, with details listed in the supporting information (Table S1). In the case of Nb/SiO2 catalyst prepared without any OAs, the catalyst is denoted as None-xNb/SiO2. In addition, a bulk Nb2O5 was calcined at 500 °C in air for 3 h, it is named as Nb2O5-500. A physical mixture sample was prepared by grinding Nb2O5 and SiO2 in a mortar. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles of the catalysts were recorded using a MiniFlex 600 (Rigaku Corp.) equipped with D/teX Ultra 250 1D detector employing a monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) generated at 40 kV and 15 mA at 2θ from 5° to 80° and a scan speed of 10°/min. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were obtained using a H-7650A transmission electron microscope (Hitachi Ltd.) at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) measurement was conducted using an IRAffinity-1S Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer (Shimadzu Corp.). The sample was diluted in KBr and pressed into a thin disk, where the IR spectra were collected at a wavenumber of 400–4000 cm−1. FT-IR spectra of pyridine (Py) adsorbed on the catalyst were conducted by the following procedure: a catalyst sample of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 (0.0647 g) was pressed into a thin disk and placed into a sample holder. After the sample holder was installed into the FT-IR cell, the sample was pre-heated at 150 °C under vacuum for 1 h. A background spectrum was collected at room temperature, and then vapor of Py was introduced into the cell at room temperature for 1 h. The physisorbed Py was removed by evacuation at room temperature for 15 min. After sequential evacuation at 150, 325, and 350 °C, the FT-IR spectra were recorded at room temperature. Temperature-programmed desorption of adsorbed NH3 and CO2 (NH3- and CO2-TPD) was performed using BELCATII (MicrotracBEL Corp.). Prior to the adsorption, a sample of ca. 0.05 g was pre-heated in a He flow at 500 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to 100 °C. The probe gas (either NH3 or CO2) was introduced at 100 °C for 1 h, and the physiosorbed gas was flushed with a He flow for 30 min. After that, the desorption of either NH3 or CO2 was monitored while the temperature of the sample was raised from 100 to 800 °C. The details of the procedure to obtain the TPD profile are described elsewhere [37,38]. Thermal gravimetry (TG) analysis was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku Corp.). After a sample had been heated at 110 °C for 1 h to remove the physisorbed water, the weight change was monitored while the sample was heated in air from 110 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using JPS-9030 (JEOL Ltd. source, MgKα; voltage, 10 kV; current, 10 mA; pass energy, 30 eV; neutralization gun: voltage, 5 V; current, 5 mA). The XPS spectra were corrected to fix the peak top of C1s XPS spectrum at 284.3 eV. 2.3 Catalytic test and poisoning experiment Vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal was performed using a fixed-bed flow-down reactor under an ambient pressure. A catalyst with a weight (W) of 0.05 – 0.5 g was placed inside the reactor and pre-heated at a reaction temperature in a flow of N2 gas for 1 h. Butanal was fed from the reactor top at a feed rate (F) of 1.55 g h−1 using N2 as carrier gas at a flow rate of 5 cm3 min−1. The reaction products were trapped using a dry-ice acetone trap and periodically collected every hour. The liquid products were identified using gas chromatography equipped with a mass spectrometer (GCMS-QP5050A, Shimadzu Corp.). They were also quantitatively analyzed with another GC (GC-8A, Shimadzu Corp.) equipped with a flame ionized detector (FID). Unless otherwise noted, the activity data, such as conversion and selectivity, were averaged at time on stream (TOS) between 1 and 5 h. To elucidate the role of acid sites of the catalyst, a poisoning experiment with NH3 gas was performed using an N2 gas with 5 % NH3 at a flow rate of 5 cm3 min−1 instead of using N2 carrier gas. To confirm the role of the base sites, a poisoning experiment with CO2 gas was performed using pure CO2 as a carrier gas at a flow rate of 5 cm3 min−1. The role of Brønsted acid sites (BAS) and Lewis acid sites (LAS) was evaluated by the poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylpyridine (DMP): the poisoning of acid sites was performed by co-feeding butanal with 5 wt% of either 2,6- or 3,5-DMP. All poisoning experiments were conducted at 250 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening Initially, we explored the catalytic activity of several None-0.5 M/SiO2 (M = Al, V, W, Zr, and Nb) catalysts at 250 °C and a W/F of 0.32 h. Table 1 summarizes the catalytic activity of several None-0.5 M/SiO2 catalysts, and Fig. S1 illustrates the time course profile of each catalyst. Table 1 (entry 1) shows that bare SiO2 support exhibited negligible catalytic activity for the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H, even though it gave a high selectivity to 2E2H. The addition of Al on SiO2 support did not enhance the catalytic activity of SiO2 (entry 2). The presence of either V or W on the SiO2 support slightly increased catalytic activity (entries 3 and 4). However, a significant improvement in catalytic activity for the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H was observed when Zr or Nb was added to SiO2 support (entries 5 and 6). It should be noted that the 0.5Nb/SiO2 catalyst demonstrated the highest catalytic activity in the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H (entry 6), prompting further investigations using this catalyst. 3.2 Effect of OA during impregnation on the catalytic activity of Nb/SiO2 catalyst Table 2 demonstrates the effect of OA, A, added during impregnation on the catalytic activity of A-2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst in the aldol condensation of butanal at 250 °C and a W/F of 0.32 h, while Fig. S2 shows the time-course profiles of A-2.0Nb/SiO2 catalysts. Even though None-2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst prepared without OAs was already active in the aldol condensation of butanal (entry 1), the use of OAs during impregnation enhanced the catalytic activity of the 2.0Nb/SiO2 catalysts (entries 2 – 7). Table 2 shows that the A-2.0Nb/SiO2 catalysts prepared with crown ethers, such as 12C4, 15C5, and 18C6 (entries 2 – 4), exhibit superior catalytic activity compared to those prepared with TEG, CA, and Sor (entries 5 – 7), although Sor has been reported as the most effective additive to disperse Cu nanoparticles on SiO2 and enhance the resulting Cu/SiO2 catalyst [36]. Previous studies have indicated that Nb precursor species can interact with these crown ethers to form complexes [39,40]. The formation of such complexes may prevent the aggregation of Nb species on the SiO2 support during calcination process, allowing for better dispersion of the resulting Nb oxide species. In contrast, the interactions of Nb precursor with TEG, CA, and Sor may not be as effective as those with the crown ethers, leading to a less dispersed Nb oxide species in the resulting Nb/SiO2 catalyst. This investigation of the effect of OAs demonstrates that 18C6 acts as the most effective OA in generating 2.0 Nb/SiO2 catalyst with the highest performance for the aldol condensation of butanal. The use of OAs did not significantly change the product distribution, as 2E2H remained the primary product of the reaction. This result indicates that the use of OAs enhances the efficiency of the Nb/SiO2 to catalyze the aldol condensation of butanal while keeping side reactions at a low rate. It is also worth noting that a small increase in the selectivity to trimers is observed, suggesting that the increase in aldol condensation efficiency promotes the consecutive aldol condensation of 2E2H to produce trimers. Tables 1 and 2 also show that a small amount of butanoic acid (BA) was produced during the aldol condensation of butanal. Even though Moggi and Albanesi have previously reported that the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal over silica-supported niobia gave a high selectivity of 2E2H without the production of BA [41], Ivanova et al. have suggested that BA can be generated from butanal via the Cannizzaro disproportionation over a solid acid Zr-BEA catalyst [17]. The presence of a small amount of BA in this work is evidence that the Cannizzaro disproportionation proceeded over Nb/SiO2 catalyst. 3.3 Effect of molar ratio of 18C6 to Nb and Nb content Fig. 2A illustrates the effect of the molar ratio of 18C6 to Nb on the catalytic activity of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst at 250 °C and a W/F of 0.32 h, while Table S2 summarizes the numerical details. Increasing the molar ratio of 18C6/Nb from 0 to 1 favors the generation of a more efficient 2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst, as the catalytic activity of the 2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst increases with the increase in the molar ratio of 18C6 to Nb. However, a further increment of the molar ratio of 18C6/Nb from 1 to 1.5 slightly decreases the catalytic activity of the resulting catalyst. Considering that 18C6 might form a complex with Nb precursor, an optimum amount of 18C6 is essential to bind Nb species effectively to prevent the aggregation of Nb species during the calcination process. Since equimolar 18C6 and Nb were required to generate the most efficient 2.0 Nb/SiO2 catalyst, it can be assumed that each 18C6 molecule is bound effectively to one Nb species. Fig. 2B shows the effect of Nb content, x, on the catalytic activity of None- and 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts, while Table S3 shows the numerical data. Across all tested x, the catalytic activity of the 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts consistently outperforms that of the None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts. For the None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts, the activity steeply increases with an increase in x from 0 to 1.5 mol%, and further increment of x to 4.0 mol% does not substantially increase the activity. In contrast, the catalytic activity of the 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts increases with the increment of x from 0 to 2.0 mol%, and no substantial change in catalytic activity is observed upon the increase in x to 4.0 mol%. These findings suggest that while 18C6 promotes better dispersion of Nb oxide species on SiO2, excessive Nb content can still hinder the efficiency of the catalyst in the aldol condensation of butanal. Fig. 3 displays the XRD profiles of None- and 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts. The characteristic of SiO2 support is clearly visible with the broad peak located around 2θ of 22.1°. The peaks associated with Nb oxide species were not visible in the 0.5 Nb/SiO2 catalysts since the Nb content was low, and the size of Nb oxide species was small. Interestingly, the peaks associated with Nb oxide species still cannot be observed even at x of 4.0 mol%, suggesting that small and highly dispersed Nb oxide species were still generated even at x = 4.0 mol%. Previous reports have also shown a similar behavior, where the diffraction peaks of Nb oxide species in the supported niobia catalyst are hardly visible after the sample is calcined at 500 °C [42,43]. Dias et al. have reported that at a low Nb content, the surface monolayer of Nb oxide species might be dispersed on the support, making it untraceable by XRD analysis [42]. The FT-IR spectra of several None- and 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts are displayed in Fig. S3. Notably, there is no substantial difference in the FT-IR spectra of the catalysts tested at x = 0.5, 2.0, and 4.0 mol%. Fig. 4 displays the TEM images of Nb/SiO2 catalyst at x = 2.0 and 4.0 mol%. No particles of Nb oxide were observed at x = 2.0 mol% in the catalyst prepared with and without 18C6. Similarly, no Nb oxide particles were visible in the 18C6–4.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst due to the high dispersion of Nb oxide nanoparticles. However, small Nb oxide particles can be observed as black dots in the None-4.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst. These results strongly indicate that the additive 18C6 is essential in ensuring the generation of small and highly dispersed Nb oxide species. The use of 18C6 in this work clearly provides Nb/SiO2 catalyst with small and highly dispersed Nb oxide species. Fig. 5 shows the Nb 3d XPS spectra of 18C6- and None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts at x = 2.0 and 4.0 mol%, while the Nb 3d XPS spectrum of bulk Nb2O5-500 and O 1s XPS spectra are displayed in Figs. S4 and S5, respectively. Similar to the previous report, the bulk Nb2O5-500 catalyst exhibits a distinct doublet of Nb 3d5/2 and Nb 3d3/2 peaks located at 206.7 and 209.4 eV, respectively, confirming the presence of Nb5+ [44]. In contrast, the 18C6- and None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts have broad peaks, attributed to Nb species with different natures. The deconvoluted results of the 18C6- and None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts with 2.7 eV of energy separation reveal two pairs of doublets, which are located at 206.7 and 209.4 eV, as well as 208.0 and 210.7 eV. Considering that the presence of Nb6+ is unlikely, while the binding energy is too high for Nb4+ [44,45], the pair of doublets suggests the presence of Nb5+ with different environments. Another report has suggested that the increase in binding energy of Nb5+ species implies the presence of highly dispersed Nb5+ species on SiO2 support [46]. Using the Nb 3d5/2 peaks located at 206.7 and 208.0 eV, the ratio of highly dispersed Nb5+ and bulk-like Nb5+ can be calculated. The ratios of these two Nb5+ species in the None-2.0Nb, None-4.0Nb, 18C6–2.0Nb, and 18C6–4.0Nb/SiO2 catalysts were 0.71, 2.28, 0.50, and 1.73, respectively. The result from the XPS spectra indicates that None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts have a higher concentration of highly dispersed Nb5+ species than 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts. 3.4 Study of the active sites: the role of acid sites in the aldol condensation of butanal To explore the possible sites that are responsible for the catalytic activity, the acid and base properties of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst were investigated using NH3- and CO2-TPD. Fig. 6 shows the TPD profiles of None- and 18C6–2.0 Nb/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 6 clearly reveals that the Nb/SiO2 catalysts mainly contain acid sites with negligible base sites. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that the aldol condensation of butanal proceeds over acid sites of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst. Since the Nb/SiO2 catalysts mainly contain acid sites, the change in catalytic activity can be attributed to the change in acid site concentration. To confirm this assumption, we first analyzed the effect of Nb content, x, on the acid concentration of None- and 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. S6 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of None- and 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts with different Nb contents. For comparison, we also display the NH3-TPD profile of Nb2O5-500 catalyst in Fig. S7. The change in x clearly alters the acid concentration of the Nb/SiO2 catalysts. The acid concentration of 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts seems to be higher than that of None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts, except for None-4.0 Nb/SiO2 catalyst. It can be said that the utilization of 18C6 during the impregnation protocol facilitates higher Nb oxide dispersion, which in turn increases the acid concentration. Table S4 summarizes the numerical data for acid concentration. Fig. 7A correlates Nb content and acid concentration of None- and 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts. Even though the acid concentration of 18C6-Nb/SiO2 catalysts is higher than that of None-Nb/SiO2 catalysts, except for None-4.0 Nb/SiO2, the trend of acid concentration to Nb content, x, is identical. The acid concentration of Nb/SiO2 catalysts increases when x is increased from 0 to 2.0 mol%, and further increment of x to 4.0 mol% decreases the acid concentration. Fig. 7B shows the relationship between Nb content and the formation rate of 2E2H. In a similar manner to the acid concentration, the formation rate of 2E2H increases with the increase in x from 0 to 2.0 mol%, and a gradual decrease in the formation rate of 2E2H was observed upon further increment of x to 4.0 mol%. These findings showcase clear evidence that the change in catalytic activity of Nb/SiO2 is highly influenced by the change in acid concentration. Fig. 8 displays the correlation between acid concentration and the formation rate of 2E2H in the aldol condensation of butanal, while Table S4 summarizes the details of the numerical data. A proportional correlation between acid concentrations and the formation rate of 2E2H is observed, suggesting that the efficiency of Nb/SiO2 catalyst for the aldol condensation of butanal depends on the concentration of acid sites. The utilization of 18C6 as an OA is proven essential in generating a catalyst with higher acid concentration, leading to a more efficient catalyst. Nevertheless, Fig. 8 also highlights the importance of optimum Nb content in ensuring the efficiency of 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalyst. The most efficient 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalyst, which contains the highest concentration of acid sites, can only be generated with the help of 18C6 at an appropriate Nb content of 2.0 mol%. This result is further corroborated by the fact that the correlation between acid concentration and the formation rate of 2E2H over None-4.0 Nb/SiO2 catalyst is similar to that of Nb2O5-500 of the unsupported bulk catalyst. In the absence of OA at a high Nb content of 4.0 mol%, Nb oxide with a bulk-like structure could be generated since the aggregation of the Nb species cannot be hindered, leading to a severe decline in catalyst efficiency. The proportional correlation between the acid concentration of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst and the acid concentration allows us to express the turnover frequency (TOF) of the Nb/SiO2, which is represented by the slope in Fig. 8. It is calculated that the TOF of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst for the aldol condensation of butanal is 463 h−1. It is also worth noting that the efficiency of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst originates from the interaction between Nb species and SiO2 support. This assumption is corroborated by the fact that the physical mixture of Nb2O5 and SiO2 support, amounting to the same Nb content of a 2.0 Nb/SiO2 catalyst, did not result in high catalytic activity (Table S4). In fact, the activity of the physical mixture of Nb2O5 and SiO2 was only slightly higher than bare SiO2 support. The NH3-TPD analysis also reveals that the physical addition of a small amount of Nb2O5 with SiO2 support marginally increases the acid concentration when compared to SiO2 support (Table S4). Consequently, a slight increment of catalytic activity was observed, although the activity remained significantly lower than that of 2.0 Nb/SiO2 catalyst prepared with the impregnation protocol. This result highlights the importance of suitable catalyst preparation in ensuring the dispersion and interaction of Nb5+ species on the SiO2 support, which consequently generates a catalyst with an optimum acid concentration for the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H. Further verification of the importance of acid sites in the aldol condensation of butanal was conducted through poisoning experiments using several probe molecules, such as NH3, CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP. Fig. 9A illustrates that the catalytic activity of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst does not decline when the base sites are poisoned by CO2. This result further corroborates the fact that the base sites of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst were negligible, as confirmed by the CO2-TPD (Fig. 6B). However, the catalytic activity of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst declined substantially when the acid sites were poisoned with NH3. This finding indicates that the hindrance to the acid sites during the reaction severely reduced the catalytic activity, which further demonstrates the importance of acid sites of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst. Fig. 9B depicts the catalytic activity of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst in the presence of either 2,6- or 3,5-DMP. 2,6-DMP can be used as a probe to demonstrate the role of BAS since it selectively blocks the BAS, while keeping the LAS exposed [47–49]. In contrast, the methyl groups in 3,5-DMP, which are located away from the N atom, allow 3,5-DMP to block both BAS and LAS [50,51]. Fig. 9B shows a substantial decrement of catalytic activity when the BAS was hindered by 2,6-DMP, implying that BAS plays an essential role in the aldol condensation of butanal. Fig. 9B also shows the poisoning effect of 3,5-DMP on the activity of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst. The presence of 3,5-DMP decreased catalytic activity. However, the decrement of the catalytic activity due to the presence of 3,5-DMP was lower than that in the presence of 2,6-DMP. Therefore, it can be assumed that the aldol condensation of butanal over 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst proceeded over its BAS. To confirm the existence of BAS and LAS on the Nb/SiO2 catalyst, the FT-IR spectra of the Py adsorbed on the catalyst were measured. Fig. 10 displays the FT-IR spectra of Py adsorbed on 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst. The bands located at 1446 and 1590 cm−1 are associated with Py adsorbed on LAS [52–54], while the band around 1544 cm−1 is characteristic of pyridinium ion adsorbed on BAS [52,53]. In addition, the band at 1489 cm−1 is assigned as the Py adsorbed on both LAS and BAS [53,54]. Notably, the band associated with BAS remained even after evacuation at 150 °C under vacuum, implying the strength of the BAS on the catalyst. The band assigned to BAS gradually diminished when the evacuation temperature was raised to 325 and 350 °C, leaving only LAS on the catalyst. The FT-IR of adsorbed Py confirmed the presence of the BAS on the 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst, while the in-situ poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP confirmed the role of this BAS in the aldol condensation. The proportional correlation between acid sites and the formation rate of 2E2H strongly suggests the importance of preparing Nb/SiO2 catalysts with high acid concentration by dispersing Nb species on SiO2 support. TEM images and XRD profiles have demonstrated the effectiveness of 18C6 as an organic additive to disperse small-sized Nb species, leading to the generation of catalysts with high acid concentration as confirmed by NH3-TPD analyses. However, these findings contradict the results from the XPS spectra, which indicate that the None-xNb/SiO2 catalysts have a higher number of highly dispersed Nb5+ species than 18C6-xNb/SiO2 catalysts. Although XPS spectra provide strong evidence for the existence of Nb5+ species on SiO2 surface, the contradiction with other relevant catalytic parameters highlights the limitation of relying solely on XPS spectra to assess the dispersion of catalytically active sites in the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H. 3.5 Stability of the 18C6-2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst The time course profiles show that the Nb/SiO2 catalysts are deactivated within a TOS of 5 h (Figs. 9, S1, and S2). Previous reports have suggested that coke accumulation leads to catalyst deactivation by blocking access to the active sites [55–58]. For the solid acid in particular, the amount of coke formed has been reported to correlate with the type, strength, and concentration of acid [57,58]. The poisoning experiments, along with the NH3- and CO2-TPD profiles, have demonstrated that the acid sites are crucial for the aldol condensation of butanal. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the deactivation of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst is caused by coke deposition on its acid sites. TG analysis was performed to evaluate the weight change of the spent catalyst, specifically examining the possible coke accumulation on the catalyst during aldol condensation. Fig. 11 illustrates the TG profiles of the fresh and spent None- and 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalysts. The weight change of the 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst, which contains a higher concentration of acid sites (Fig. S6), was higher than that of None-2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst. This result indicates that the 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst contains more carbonaceous species than the None-2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst, suggesting that the aldol condensation of butanal indeed proceeds on the acid sites. Given that the formation of coke occurs on these acid sites, it is reasonable to assume that the accumulated coke blocks the access to acid sites, leading to catalyst deactivation. Fig. 12 demonstrates the regeneration tests of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst. The spent 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 was calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. According to the TG profiles in Fig. 11, this condition is sufficient to remove the accumulated coke. Fig. 12 exhibits that the catalytic activity of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst is recovered after the regeneration process, indicating that coke accumulation is the primary cause for the catalyst deactivation. Furthermore, this result was corroborated by the XRD profiles shown in Fig. S8. The peaks associated with the Nb species were not observed in the XRD profiles of the spent None- and 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalysts, demonstrating that aggregation of Nb species did not occur. Reasonably, the removal of accumulated coke would not recover the catalytic activity of the spent 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 catalyst if severe aggregation of Nb species had occurred during aldol condensation. 3.6 Plausible reaction mechanism The importance of acid sites, especially BAS, has been revealed by poisoning experiments using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP. Numerous reports have suggested that the local structure of BAS in the supported Nb catalyst originates from the Nb-OH or Nb-OH-Si sites [43,59,60]. This OH group has been reported to be more acidic than the OH group in bare Nb2O5 and SiO2 [43,61]. In addition, the Nb-OH sites have been previously considered as active sites in numerous catalytic reactions, such as glycerol dehydration [59], alkene epoxidation [60], xylose dehydration [62], and Friedel-Crafts alkylation [62]. Referring to the poisoning experiments results and previously reported findings, we propose a plausible mechanism of the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H over the BAS of Nb/SiO2 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 13. Butanal is predicted to be adsorbed on the BAS of the catalyst using its C = O site, similar to the report by Chin et al. [63]. The protonation of the C = O moiety allows the abstraction of the α-H even in the absence of a strong base site, producing enol in the process. Considering that enol was not observed in the reaction product, it can be predicted that this species remains adsorbed on the catalyst. This behavior also allows the formation of a C-C bond with the new incoming butanal, which eventually leads to the production of 2E2H. In the speculative mechanism of the aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H (Fig. 13), the catalytic cycle turns over the BAS of Nb/SiO2 catalyst. Table S5 summarizes the catalytic activity of several reported catalysts for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal. Moggi et al. have reported the use of supported solid acid for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal, achieving a high yield of the desired product [41]. However, the full extent of the catalytic performance was rather difficult to disclose. Modifying the catalyst with base species was proven to improve the selectivity to 2E2H (entries 2 – 4). However, basic catalysts such as MgO/SiO2, SrO/SiO2 [4], and NaX [16] are seriously deactivated. In addition, the performance of these solid base catalysts is inferior to that of 18C6–2.0Nb/SiO2 (entry 8). Previously, we have also demonstrated that SiO2 and TiO2-Ag catalysts are active in the aldol condensation of butanal, giving butanal conversion of nearly 50 % (entries 5 and 6). The performance of solid acid, such as Zr-BEA, is proven promising with selectivity to 2E2H of 85 mol% (entry 7), even though it has a lower conversion than the present Nb/SiO2 catalyst. Several heterogeneous catalysts have also been employed in the liquid-phase aldol condensation of butanal (entries 9 – 12). In some works, the aldol condensation of butanal is combined with hydrogenation to generate the respective saturated alcohol, 2-ethyl-1-hexanol. Although full conversion with high selectivity can be achieved using liquid-phase catalytic systems, the overall productivity of the desired product from these catalysts is smaller than that of our catalyst. Moreover, the use of pressurized hydrogen gas will pose a challenge for industrial scale-up. Previously, we have also reported that intramolecular aldol condensation of 2,5-hexanedione to 3-methyl-2-cyclopentenone can be catalyzed by solid base catalysts, such as Y2Zr2O7, ZrO2, and CeO2, at reaction temperatures higher than 300 °C [64,65]. Nevertheless, those basic catalysts were ineffective for the aldol condensation of butanal under the reaction conditions similar to those of Table 1 (conversion of butanal was less than 0.2 %). These findings showcase that the OA-impregnation protocol is effective in generating an efficient supported solid acid catalyst for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H. 4 Conclusion The vapor-phase self-aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H proceeded efficiently over the Nb/SiO2 catalyst prepared via an OA-assisted impregnation. Among several OAs tested, 18C6 generated the Nb/SiO2 catalyst with the highest efficiency. At an optimum Nb content of 2.0 mol%, the use of 18C6 highly dispersed Nb oxide species on SiO2, leading to the formation of the catalyst with the most abundant acid sites. The importance of the acid sites was verified by the proportional correlation between the formation rate of 2E2H and the acid concentrations. Furthermore, the hindrance to acid sites, in particular BAS, clearly reduced the catalytic activity of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst, implying that the aldol condensation of butanal proceeds over the BAS of Nb/SiO2 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we prepared SiO2-supported niobium oxide (Nb/SiO2) catalysts with optimized acid concentrations using an organic additive (OA)-assisted impregnation protocol for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal to 2-ethyl-2-hexenal (2E2H). The inclusion of an OA, such as 18-crown-6-ether, during the impregnation process enhanced the acid concentration of the resulting Nb/SiO2 catalyst. This increase in acid concentration proved to be crucial for the vapor-phase aldol condensation of butanal to 2E2H, as confirmed by a proportional correlation between the acid concentration and the formation rate of 2E2H. Additionally, the essential role of acid sites, in particular Brønsted acid sites, of the Nb/SiO2 catalyst was confirmed through poisoning experiments using several probe molecules, including NH3, CO2, and 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylpyridine. Several other parameters, such as Nb content and molar ratio of OA to Nb, also affected the catalytic activity of Nb/SiO2 catalyst.
